Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2008 12:35PM Lilac wrote: Dear Stephanie,  I'll be praying for you especially for no more brain mets.  I think we will know when it is time to give up the fight.  For some of us, it will be out of our hands, for others, a decision will have to be made to stop treatment.  I imagine that we all wonder how it will go for ourselves.  I do.  I'm not ready to give up yet, but nothing that I've tried this year has stopped the progression of my cancer, so am beginning to wonder if anything will and if there IS something, will we find it in time to give me  quality of life.    But, we are here today, aren't we, and at least where I live, it is a beautiful day, one certainly worth living for.  You are in my prayers as are all the women on this board.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 06:52AM Lilac wrote: LuAnn, I just want to add to what everyone else has written here.  You are no way a loser!  We all need to vent now and then, some of us need to do it more than others.  I'm so glad that your son will be out of harms way and home soon.  That will take some of the stress off of you, stress you don't need right now.  Your health should come first for you, and then the family.  I've been learning that the hard way, myself, and have found it to be true.  I hope you can get outside and get some fresh air and sunshine on that beautiful face.  It will make you feel better, I promise.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 08:35AM Lilac wrote: Annie, I just want to welcome you back.  I wish I had some information that could help you with your medical questions, but I don't.  I can relate to the children and grands situation, tho.  It is so frustrating to disappoint your children when you aren't feeling well.  It's hard for them to understand.  I look fine, and so should be as active as before.  But oh, those grands, they bring me such joy that I can't even express it and they don't mind if I just sit and read to them or hold them or lie on the floor and play cars and airplanes with them.  I'm off the Xeloda for now and only on Ixempra and Zometa.  I feel much better so far (2 days), but understand that Ixempra can have some weird side effects.  We'll see.  I wish you well.

Posts.Title: Thinking about quiting chemo Lilac Godsgal

Posts.Content: Lilac wrote: I'm pretty sure this has been discussed before, but would like to hear your thoughts.  My QOL has been in the pits lately and I'm oh so tired of it.  I have a wonderful, loving DH who will do anything for me but he is so full of life and energetic and I am so sick all the time that all I want to do is lie down.  I have tumors in my spine that don't cause me much trouble and a bunch of them on my liver.  I think the chemo is making my life miserable.  In the end, what will it get me, one month, six months?  But they will be miserable months.  I look so healthy, you'd never guess that I had cancer.  Maybe without chemo I'd have another good year, who knows.  Of course, that's the answer, nobody knows.  I have 5 adult kids and 4 little grands who I'd love to be here for but I can't even enjoy them now when all I want to do is be alone and sleep. I'm sick to my stomach all the time - nausea. So I'm thinking of quitting chemo, maybe staying on the zometa maybe trying an hormonal if my Dr. saw any reason to do that,  Currently I'm on Ixempra and it may be keeping me stable. Any thoughts?  Dx 11/22/2006, Stage IV, 4/25 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Thinking about quiting chemo Lilac Godsgal

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 09:26AM - edited Apr 12, 2009 09:29AM by Lilac I think that part of it is, LynnW, is that I'm losing hope that there is a chemo for me out there.  I've tried so many this year with continued progression.  This Ixempra is giving me a little hope for more time, but I'm so sick( from the chemo,) I imagine. Thank you all for your thoughts and Lena for a very thoughtful post with lots of info to think about. I got up sick again this a.m., Easter Sunday.  I'd love to go to Mass, but I feel like crap and just can't do it.  Is a little thing like that too much to ask for QOL?  Lilac Don't misunderstand, I'm not ready to die, I'm just wondering if the time I have left would be better without all the poisons that I'm putting into myself.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 02:02PM Lilac wrote: I had my port placed yesterday, a Bard power port.  Can be used for the scans.   I also had my first chemo infusion yesterday with the port.  Getting Navelbine also Zometa.  I'm so glad to have it as I've had bi-lateral mastectomies and large number of lymph nodes removed from both sides.  Having the bloodwork and scans has been so stressful for me.  This my second port.  First one broke shortly after I finished chemo 4 yrs ago.  You're going to love having a port.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 02:15PM Lilac wrote: It looks like you are ruling out Moffitt as an option, but I recommend Dr. Susan Minton over there.  She's not a surgeon, but a wonderful and caring oncologist.  She's very busy, tho, and seems to take a lot of time off.  I've also heard really good things about Dr. Christopher George and Dr. Blanco, Bay Area Oncology.  Their office is very close to St. Joseph's Hospital in Tampa.  My daughter sees Dr. George for a blood disorder and she loves him.  I'm sorry you're having such a frustrating experience.
